design_intent.player_goal: Collect, preserve, and explain digital evidence without wrecking its admissibility.

trap_list.name: Logical copy ≠ forensic image
trap_list.misconception: Copying files/folders is enough for forensic work.
trap_list.fix: A forensic image is bit-for-bit and preserves metadata, unallocated/slack space, and deleted remnants; a logical copy usually won’t.

trap_list.name: Hash is a fingerprint; checksum is a basic integrity check
trap_list.fix: Both can detect changes, but hashes are used as unique identifiers/fingerprints for evidence integrity and provenance.

trap_list.name: MD5/SHA1 can still show identical copies (in non-adversarial contexts)
trap_list.misconception: MD5/SHA1 are ‘broken’ so they are never used in forensics.
trap_list.fix: They’re weak against deliberate collision attacks, but still commonly used to quickly verify forensic image integrity when adversarial collisions aren’t the main concern.

trap_list.name: Grab the volatile stuff first
trap_list.misconception: Always power off immediately and image the disk first.
trap_list.fix: Follow the order of volatility: volatile state (RAM/ephemeral tables) can vanish on shutdown; capture it first unless a compelling reason exists.

trap_list.name: If you didn’t use a write blocker, your case can implode
trap_list.fix: Write blockers prevent any writes to the evidence drive during examination, protecting integrity/admissibility.

trap_list.name: You usually can’t ‘image the SaaS’
trap_list.misconception: You can install your imaging agent inside a SaaS provider and pull a disk image whenever you want.
trap_list.fix: Cloud providers rarely allow direct forensic acquisition of their service infrastructure; plan for logs, contracts, and available provider tooling instead.

trap_list.name: SSDs don’t behave like spinning disks
trap_list.misconception: Secure delete guarantees SSD data is unrecoverable.
trap_list.fix: Wear leveling and reserved blocks can leave old data behind; full-disk encryption helps mitigate residual recoverability.

trap_list.name: Snapshot beats imaging the whole host
trap_list.misconception: To image a VM you must power it down and image the entire virtualization host.
trap_list.fix: VM snapshots capture the VM state without dragging in unrelated host/tenant data and without massive disruption.

trap_list.name: Bad clocks make bad timelines
trap_list.misconception: If one system shows the incident an hour earlier, the attacker must have moved laterally slowly.
trap_list.fix: Time zones/clock drift can shift timestamps; verify time settings before drawing timeline conclusions.

missions.name: Forensics Fundamentals
missions.goal: Know what digital forensics is for, and how documentation makes evidence usable.

missions.name: Legal Gravity
missions.goal: Handle legal holds, avoid spoliation, and understand e‑discovery/EDRM stages.

mechanics.hazard: One distractor per question is a courtroom trap.

missions.name: Volatility Sprint
missions.goal: Capture the right artifacts in the right order before they evaporate.

mechanics.rule: Wrong order breaks your streak bonus.

missions.name: Imaging Forge
missions.goal: Choose proper acquisition tools and distinguish forensic images from logical copies.

mechanics.modifier: Tool choice matters more than tool name.

missions.name: Integrity & Preservation
missions.goal: Prove your evidence is unchanged and preserve it correctly across the whole lifecycle.

missions.name: Clouds, Networks, and Weird Targets
missions.goal: Do forensics when the evidence lives in the cloud, on the wire, or inside ephemeral platforms.

mechanics.twist: Some evidence cannot be directly acquired.

boss.name: Boss: The Missing Chain
boss.premise: A lawsuit and an incident collide: you must preserve evidence, image the right systems, prove integrity, and write a report that survives court scrutiny.

mechanics.phase_1: Trigger legal hold + protect against spoliation.
mechanics.phase_2: Acquire volatile data + image disks/VMs correctly.
mechanics.phase_3: Validate hashes + maintain chain of custody + deliver a clear report.

constraint_cards.name: Hostile Counsel
constraint_cards.effect: Your preservation and write-blocking choices are heavily weighted.

constraint_cards.name: Time Skew
constraint_cards.effect: Timeline questions include misleading timestamps/time zones.

constraint_cards.name: No Full Packet Capture
constraint_cards.effect: Rely on logs and metadata; packet data is incomplete.

question_bank.stem: Place these EDRM stages in a sensible high-level order (earliest → latest).
question_bank.explanation: EDRM flows from knowing what exists (identify), protecting it (preserve), gathering it (collect), validating suitability (review), handing it over (produce), and using it (present). The trap is swapping preservation and collection—collecting without preservation risks alteration.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: EDRM flows from knowing what exists (identify), protecting it (preserve), gathering it (collect), validating suitability (review), handing it over (produce), and using it (present).

question_bank.stem: Match each EDRM stage to what it focuses on.
right: Identify key topics/terms/people from the data
Assess/control what data exists before a case

pairs.Analysis: Identify key topics/terms/people from the data
pairs.Information governance: Assess/control what data exists before a case

question_bank.explanation: EDRM separates preparing data (processing) from meaning-making (analysis). Information governance happens ‘before the fact’ so you can scope what exists. The trap is confusing processing and analysis as the same step.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: EDRM separates preparing data (processing) from meaning-making (analysis).
